The Royal Engineers are trained to be versatile and adaptable, and they receive specific training for each type of deployment. This training is designed to ensure that they have the skills and knowledge they need to respond effectively to a wide range of situations, whether in combat or during disaster relief operations.

Before a deployment, Royal Engineers will typically receive pre-deployment training, where they will learn about the specific context of the operation and the local culture they will be working in. The training will also cover the technical skills they will need for the deployment, such as explosive ordnance disposal, bridge building, or water and sanitation.

During the deployment itself, Royal Engineers are expected to be flexible and adaptable. They will often need to work in difficult and challenging circumstances, and they need to be able to think on their feet and improvise solutions. They will also need to work effectively alongside other military units and civilian organizations, collaborating to achieve the mission objectives.

In summary, the Royal Engineers receive specific training for each type of deployment, but they are also expected to be able to adapt on the fly as situations arise. This versatility and adaptability are among the key strengths of the Royal Engineers, enabling them to respond effectively to a wide range of scenarios and accomplish their mission objectives in a variety of situations.
